keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter, was pardoned by President Donald Trump in 2021 and later arrested for making a credible death threat against U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan allegedly planned to kill Jeffries during a speech at the Economic Club of New York, with text messages indicating a clear intent to carry out a fatal attack.
The threat was considered credible and serious, prompting federal and state law enforcement to act, with Jeffries publicly thanking officials for preventing a potential assassination.
Moynihan was initially sentenced to 21 months in prison in 2023 for breaching the Capitol on January 6, 2021, and was one of the first rioters to break through police lines.
After the pardon, Moynihan became a symbol of the controversy over executive clemency for violent political offenders, with other pardoned rioters also facing new charges.
The case reflects broader concerns about political violence in the U.S. in 2025, including recent assassinations of Democratic lawmakers and attacks on conservative figures.
This incident underscores the ongoing tension between political accountability and executive pardons in the context of national security and democratic integrity.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter pardoned by President Donald Trump in January 2021, has been arrested in New York for allegedly threatening to kill House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries during a speech. Moynihan, who was sentenced to 21 months in prison in 2023 for breaching police lines on January 6, 2021, reportedly planned to target Jeffries at the Economic Club of New York, with text messages indicating a clear intent to kill. The threat prompted law enforcement intervention and Jeffries publicly thanked agents for preventing a credible assassination. This case underscores the controversy surrounding executive pardons for violent political offenders and reflects a broader pattern of political violence in the United States in 2025, including recent attacks on Democratic and conservative figures.
